body.p: The APNA Board of Directors launched their 2012 agenda with a focus toward the future. The work of our first face-to-face meeting this year was to develop APNA’s 2012 strategic plan. However, to be effective, planning for the future must include a review of the past. We began this next strategic plan development cycle by reviewing our progress toward achieving our current strategic plan goals developed in 2009 for the time period through 2014. To ensure that APNA continues to be an inclusionary and transparent organization, it is my plan to share with you in the upcoming Board of Directors columns the process and outcome of our 2012 strategic plan development. In this issue, I would like to summarize for you the Board of Directors’ view of our progress in meeting the goals laid out in the 2009 strategic plan.

A strategic plan is the outcome of “strategic thinking” (Crouch, 2012), the goal of which is to establish a clear direction, guide the allocation of resources, and assist in focusing and aligning the organization’s goals. The plan is not an operational plan that simply outlines what is needed to maintain the current activities of the organization. Rather, a strategic plan is a roadmap to change. It outlines the organization’s prioritized goals for the future and as such directs the decision making, choices for involvements, and allocation of resources for our organization.
The 2009 Strategic Goals, designed to be accomplished by 2014, include the following:

list-item.p: APNA will be the indispensable resource for member networking and professional development.
APNA will be financially secure and stable.
APNA will be the leader in creating strategic alliances with key stakeholders.
APNA will be recognized as the expert voice for psychiatric-mental health nursing.

body.p: A review of our annual reports for the past few years offers concrete evidence that we are accomplishing these, and while they are not static but dynamic and ongoing, the current Board and senior staff are confident that we are in a sound position to move forward and revise/add to our goals, if desired and needed by our members. For each of the goals the plan provided milestones to help measure our progress; the full version of the status of the plan is available to our members at http://www.apna.org/i4a/pages/index.cfm?pageid=3287. The following are some highlights:

list-item.p: APNA will be the indispensable resource for member networking and professional development.
Member Bridge has provided a forum for all members to easily connect and network electronically.
Retention rate prior to 2009 was at best 75%, as of February 2012 it is up to 85%.
As of January 2012 an average of 6 new members join daily.
Dues collected, an indication of member growth, have grown by 14% and 12%, respectively, in the last two fiscal years.
Our most recent annual conference in October 2011 had the largest attendance since its inception.
APNA’s Clinical Psychopharmacology Institute also saw increased attendance in June 2011.
E-learning Center has made multiple quality education programs available to all our members:
2011 added more than 130 hours of accredited education via podcasts from APNA’s CPI and Annual Conference
Increase in member generated continuing education programs for skill enhancement

Communication to our members is robust through blast emails, Member Bridge announcements, Facebook “share” and Twitter “tweet” buttons, and APNA News to name a few. The addition of press releases allows for our messages to be delivered beyond our current membership.
Participation in councils, task forces, and committees is strong as evidenced by Council Expert Panel numbers consistently ranging from 100 to 150 members.
APNA will be financially secure and stable.
A comparison of APNA’s balance sheet between December 31, 2008, and December 31, 2011, shows an increase in fund balance of plus $719,398 (an increase of 102%).
APNA will be the leader in creating strategic alliances with key stakeholders.
APNA has built strong relationships, positive alliances, and strategic partnerships and coalitions with key nursing and allied health organizations, including, but not limited to:

American Nurses Association, Nursing Organization’s Alliance, American Association of Colleges of Nursing, American Nurses Credentialing Center, Emergency Nurses Association, International Society of Psychiatric Nursing, National Student Nurses Association, National Council of State Boards of Nursing, Substance Abuse and Mental Health Association, National Organization of Nurse Practitioners Faculties, Coalition for Patients Rights, and LACE, to name several.
APNA will be recognized as the expert voice for psychiatric-mental health nursing.
APNA is now the “go-to” organization for all things related to psychiatric-mental health nursing as well as other areas of nursing that seek our input, feedback, and/or commentary.

When the Emergency Nurses Association began their project for an online education program about the care for psychiatric patients in the emergency departments they sought us out and have since included us in the totality of their project.
The American Nurses Association asked us to comment on their position papers regarding staffing and restraint and seclusion.
The Center for Medicare and Medicaid solicited our comments regarding their proposed rules for Conditions of Participation.
Horatio, the European psychiatric nursing organization, approached us to disseminate their Turko Agreement, which is an international scope and standards of practice for psychiatric nursing.

body.p: As you can see we have been quite successful with our early strategic plan. This success rests on your shoulders, and your active involvement in all our activities continues to keep us vital and strong. We are thankful to all of you who have donated your time and expertise.
Our future columns will keep you abreast of this ongoing strategic planning process, and we will update you in our next edition.
